docs.title: Welcome to EmpiricML
docs.text: Python framework for building robust tabular machine learning models faster and easier

docs.title: What is EmpiricML?
docs.text: EmpiricML is a comprehensive Python framework designed to simplify the process of building, training, and evaluating machine learning models for tabular data. It provides a unified interface for working with popular ML libraries like scikit-learn, LightGBM, XGBoost, CatBoost, and PyTorch.

docs.title: Key Features
docs.text:
• Rapid Prototyping

    Build and compare multiple models quickly with minimal boilerplate code

  • Unified API

    Consistent interface across different ML frameworks and algorithms

  • Built-in Evaluation

    Comprehensive metrics and visualization tools for model assessment

  • Data Processing

    Streamlined preprocessing pipelines for tabular data

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
import EmpiricML as eml

# Load your data
data = eml.Dataset.from_csv("your_data.csv", target="target_column")

# Build and train a model
model = eml.Model("lightgbm")
model.fit(data)

# Evaluate performance
results = model.evaluate(data)
print(results.summary())

docs.title: Installation
docs.text: pip install EmpiricML

docs.text:
• Initial release

  • XGBoost wrapper (XGBWrapper)

docs.title: Contributing
docs.text: Thank you for your interest in contributing to EmpiricML! 🎉

docs.title: Reporting Bugs
docs.text:
1. Check if the bug has already been reported in GitHub Issues
  2. If not, create a new issue with:
  3. A clear title and description
  4. Steps to reproduce the bug
  5. Expected vs actual behavior
  6. Your environment details

docs.title: Suggesting Features
docs.text: Open an issue with the enhancement label describing your feature request.

docs.title: Pull Requests
docs.text:
1. Fork the repository
  2. Create a feature branch: git checkout -b feature/your-feature
  3. Make your changes
  4. Add tests if applicable
  5. Submit a pull request

docs.title: Development Setup
docs.text:
git clone https://github.com/PasqualeTrani/EmpiricML.git
cd EmpiricML
pip install -e ".[dev]"

docs.title: Code Style
docs.text:
• Follow PEP 8 guidelines
  • Add docstrings to all public functions
  • Write unit tests for new features

import EmpiricML as eml

docs.title: Models API Reference
docs.text: This section documents all model wrappers in EmpiricML.

docs.title: LightGBM Wrapper
docs.text:
from EmpiricML import LGBMWrapper

model = LGBMWrapper()
model.fit(X_train, y_train)
predictions = model.predict(X_test)

docs.title: XGBoost Wrapper
docs.text:
from EmpiricML import XGBWrapper

model = XGBWrapper()
model.fit(X_train, y_train)
predictions = model.predict(X_test)

docs.title: CatBoost Wrapper
docs.text:
from EmpiricML import CatBoostWrapper

model = CatBoostWrapper()
model.fit(X_train, y_train)
predictions = model.predict(X_test)

docs.title: PyTorch Wrapper
docs.text:
from EmpiricML import TorchWrapper

model = TorchWrapper(model_class=YourNeuralNetwork)
model.fit(X_train, y_train)
predictions = model.predict(X_test)

Detailed API documentation coming soon...

docs.title: Tutorials
docs.text: Learn EmpiricML through hands-on tutorials.

docs.title: Classification with LightGBM
docs.text:
A step-by-step guide to building a classification model:

import EmpiricML as eml
from sklearn.datasets import make_classification
from sklearn.model_selection import train_test_split

# Generate sample data
X, y = make_classification(n_samples=1000, n_features=20, random_state=42)
X_train, X_test, y_train, y_test = train_test_split(X, y, test_size=0.2)

# Train model
model = eml.LGBMWrapper()
model.fit(X_train, y_train)

# Evaluate
predictions = model.predict(X_test)

docs.title: Basic Concepts
docs.text: Understanding the core concepts of EmpiricML will help you get the most out of the framework.

docs.title: Architecture Overview
docs.text:
graph TD
    A[Your Data] --> B[EmpiricML]
    B --> C[Model Wrappers]
    C --> D[LightGBM]
    C --> E[XGBoost]
    C --> F[CatBoost]
    C --> G[PyTorch]
    B --> H[Evaluation]
    H --> I[Metrics]
    H --> J[Visualizations]

docs.title: Model Wrappers
docs.text:
EmpiricML provides unified wrappers around popular ML libraries. Each wrapper follows a consistent API:

Wrapper Underlying Library Best For LGBMWrapper LightGBM Large datasets, fast training XGBWrapper XGBoost General gradient boosting CatBoostWrapper CatBoost Categorical features TorchWrapper PyTorch Custom neural networks

docs.title: The Wrapper Pattern
docs.text:
All wrappers implement a common interface:

# Common methods across all wrappers
model.fit(X, y)           # Train the model
model.predict(X)          # Make predictions
model.predict_proba(X)    # Get probability estimates

docs.title: Key Principles
docs.text:
Consistency

All model wrappers share the same interface, making it easy to swap between different algorithms.

Flexibility

You can customize any model by passing parameters directly to the wrapper.

Extensibility

Create your own wrappers by inheriting from the base classes.

docs.title: Data Flow
docs.text:
1. Input Data: Start with pandas DataFrames or numpy arrays
  2. Preprocessing: Apply transformations as needed
  3. Training: Fit your chosen model
  4. Prediction: Generate predictions on new data
  5. Evaluation: Assess model performance with built-in metrics

docs.title: Requirements
docs.text:
• Python 3.11 or higher
  • pip (Python package installer)

docs.title: Install via pip
docs.text:
The recommended way to install EmpiricML is via pip:

pip install EmpiricML

docs.title: Install from Source
docs.text:
To install the latest development version from GitHub:

git clone https://github.com/PasqualeTrani/EmpiricML.git
cd EmpiricML
pip install -e .

docs.title: Dependencies
docs.text:
EmpiricML automatically installs the following dependencies:

Package Minimum Version Description numpy 1.26.4 Numerical computing pandas 2.2.2 Data manipulation polars 1.31.0 Fast DataFrames scikit-learn 1.7.1 Machine learning algorithms lightgbm 4.6.0 Gradient boosting xgboost 3.1.2 Extreme gradient boosting catboost 1.2.8 Categorical boosting matplotlib 3.9.0 Visualization skorch 1.3.1 PyTorch scikit-learn wrapper

docs.title: Optional Dependencies
docs.text:
For PyTorch-based models, you'll also need to install PyTorch:

pip install torch

docs.title: Verify Installation
docs.text:
After installation, verify that EmpiricML is correctly installed:

import EmpiricML as eml
print(eml.__version__)

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text:
CatBoost Installation on Windows

If you encounter issues installing CatBoost on Windows, try: 

pip install catboost --no-cache-dir

Virtual Environment

We recommend using a virtual environment to avoid dependency conflicts: 

python -m venv venv
source venv/bin/activate  # On Windows: venv\Scripts\activate
pip install EmpiricML

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text: Get up and running with EmpiricML in just a few minutes!

docs.title: Your First Model
docs.text: This guide will walk you through building your first machine learning model with EmpiricML.

docs.title: Step 1: Import EmpiricML
docs.text:
import EmpiricML as eml
import pandas as pd

docs.title: Step 2: Load Your Data
docs.text:
# Load data from a CSV file
df = pd.read_csv("your_data.csv")

# Or create sample data
from sklearn.datasets import make_classification

X, y = make_classification(n_samples=1000, n_features=20, random_state=42)

docs.title: Step 3: Train a Model
docs.text:
# Create and train a LightGBM model
model = eml.LGBMWrapper()
model.fit(X_train, y_train)

# Make predictions
predictions = model.predict(X_test)

docs.title: Step 4: Evaluate Performance
docs.text:
from sklearn.metrics import accuracy_score, classification_report

accuracy = accuracy_score(y_test, predictions)
print(f"Accuracy: {accuracy:.4f}")
print(classification_report(y_test, predictions))

docs.title: Working with Different Models
docs.text:
EmpiricML supports multiple model types:

LightGBMXGBoostCatBoostPyTorch Neural Network 
model = eml.LGBMWrapper()
model.fit(X_train, y_train)

model = eml.XGBWrapper()
model.fit(X_train, y_train)

model = eml.CatBoostWrapper()
model.fit(X_train, y_train)

model = eml.TorchWrapper(model_class=YourNeuralNetwork)
model.fit(X_train, y_train)
